title: 109_hr5892
content: The "Farmers Tax Deferral Act" allows for the nontaxable exchange of qualified agricultural property for real property under Section 1046 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. No gain or loss recognized for qualified person receiving US real property in exchange for qualified agricultural property. Qualified person defined as individual age 55+, corporation owned by individuals 55+, or partnership/trust/estate with all beneficial interests owned by individuals 55+. Qualified agricultural property includes agricultural structures placed in service by the taxpayer over 20 years before transfer and related real property, equipment, or fixtures. For tax purposes, "United States real property" refers to real property located in the United States. Any property received in an exchange must be identified within 45 days and completed within 180 days to be treated as real property. The rules regarding basis, exchanges not solely in kind, and related parties apply to property exchanges. The property must be identified within 45 days and completed within 180 days to be treated as real property. Rules similar to subsections (b), (c), (d), (f), and (g) of section 1031 apply for this section. A transaction described here is treated like a section 1031 exchange for tax purposes. Additionally, a special rule for like-kind exchanges of qualified agricultural property defers ordinary income recapture until the disposition of the real property acquired in the exchange. If qualified agricultural property is disposed of without recognizing gain under section 1046, the transferor's gain under subsection (a)(1) is limited to the recognized gain on the disposition plus the fair market value of property. The fair market value of property acquired not taken into account under certain conditions. If US real property acquired in an exchange is disposed of, ordinary income recapture applies. The excess of the amount realized on the disposition of real property over the adjusted basis, or the excess of the gain amount. The excess gain from selling qualified agricultural property over the ordinary income recognized on the disposition. The amendments made by this Act treat gain from selling qualified agricultural property as ordinary income, regardless of other provisions. The effective date for these amendments varies based on the type of transfer or disposition. Special rules apply to installment sales of qualified agricultural property. Special rule for qualified agricultural property in installment sales under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Special rule for qualified agricultural property in installment sales under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Income from the installment sale shall be taken into account under the installment method, and recognized income for any taxable year shall be recognized as recapture income in the same proportion to the aggregate recapture income from the sale. The amendments made by this section apply to sales after the enactment of this Act, with changes to section 453(i) of the Internal Revenue Code.
